critique: This executive order, issued in 1940, restricts the possession and use of cameras on vessels transiting the Panama Canal. This appears to be motivated by national security concerns related to potential espionage or sabotage, given the context of the time period leading up to World War II. It does not directly address immigration, economic regulation, or social inclusion. The order expands executive power by granting the Governor of the Panama Canal authority to control photography and camera possession. It also centralizes control at the federal level, as the Panama Canal Zone was under U.S. jurisdiction. The order leans towards prioritizing national security over individual liberties, specifically the freedom to take photographs. There is no clear ideological tilt in terms of liberal vs. conservative.
